bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (18:13): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: We could just make Hixie add "This document is valid HTML5" to one of the normative sections, and you wouldn't have to worry ever again ;)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:13): bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2: :)

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:14): bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2: But it is always conforming, or only the copy that Hixie publishes (i.e., if I run it through my spec-gen, is it still valid?)?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:16): bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2: That seems insufficiently verbose

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:16): Maybe "An HTML 5 document is a conforming document if it either follows all the conformance requirements described in this specification, or if it is this specification"
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:18): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, how does a validator correctly identify a document as being the spec?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:19): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: It could hardcode the MD5 of the spec
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:20): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: If it goes through my spec-gen, it will have a different MD5, and yet will still be the spec
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:20): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Also, what if Hixie updates the spec?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:20): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: It could hardcode the MD5 of all versions of the spec
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:20): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Including all possible future versions of the spec (i.e., every possible md5 hash)?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:20): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: The validator would have to be updated, which is what already has to happen for many spec changes
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (18:21): Would it be the w3c or whatwg version that was valid?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:21): does the conformance criteria implictly apply to all prior versions of the spec too, even though they are obsolete?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:27): http://bugs a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554.com/issues/show/15 ‚Äî anyone agree with that?

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:30): bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2: it shouldn't :P
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:30): Basically, should whitespace have meaning within pre for non-visual UAs?
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (18:30): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: And it shouldn't 500 either :P
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:32): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Yes, because otherwise you wouldn't be able to teach blind programmers Python
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:32): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: so <pre><dfn> foo bar </dfn></pre> <span>foo bar</span> should be xref'd how? :P
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:33): Should it not be as the span doesn't start with whitespace?
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (18:33): I would warn/error on non-trimmed dfn contents
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:34): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: That's a totally unrelated question :-p
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:34): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Totally? It's completely related to the meaning of whitespace in pre! :P
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (18:35): I think a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 is saying his script is a non-visual UA
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:35): s/non-visual UA/not a visual UA/g
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:35): how about that?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:36): well, it is a UA
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:36): and non visual
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:36): and no scripting support :)
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (18:37): Lies, it supports arbitrary script execution through vulnerabilities
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:37): bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2: Does it, though? :P

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:37): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Your UA doesn't know or care about meaning - it's just doing fuzzy string matching, and your second question was about how much fuzziness you want
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:38): the fuzziness should be based on the meaning :)
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (18:38): I repeat my suggestion
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (18:38): It avoids having to make a decision by putting the onus on the author

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:41): If you cared much about meaning, you'd recognise that <dfn>foo bar</dfn> and <span>foo bars</span> are referring to the same concept, just with some modifications to cope with grammar, and automatically link those together
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (18:43): Should he also recognize Attorneys General as referring to the singular form? :)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:43): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Peh. That means using a natural language parser (yuk)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:43): bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2: Of course
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:44): And it has to be i18nised so it'll cope with all natural languages that people will translate specs into
